raw_text:
Dunne keen to commit to Man City
 
 Richard Dunne is ready to commit his long-term future to Manchester City after turning his career around.
 
 He was once threatened with the sack by City boss Kevin Keegan but has since responded with impressive performances, prompting interest from other clubs. Early talks have taken place and the defender said: "Hopefully something will be sorted out as soon as possible. "I definitely want to stay at City because I have really improved as a player here." Newcastle boss Graeme Souness is said to have been impressed enough by Dunne's turnaround in form to be ready to make a bid for the big stopper in the January transfer window. But the 25-year-old Dubliner underlined his intention to stay at Eastlands. He added: "It's nice to be linked with top clubs but the important thing is this one and what we do. "I really enjoy it at City and I want to keep that going." Keegan is expected to be told there will be no funds to bring in fresh faces in January. Dunne's professionalism was famously questioned by Keegan, who ordered the defender home after he allegedly turned up for training in a dishevelled state.
 
 But Dunne is keen to put that period of his life behind him and said: "I've grown up a lot and the manager sees me as one of the most experienced players in the squad. "I've played more games than any other outfield players this season so I can't be regarded as being a kid any more. "I have to use that as added pressure to perform and apart from the games at Newcastle and Middlesbrough, defensively we've done quite well." Keegan is set for another boost when goalkeeper Nicky Weaver makes his long-awaited return in a reserve game at Blackburn on Tuesday. Former England Under-21 keeper Weaver has missed nearly three full seasons with a succession of knee injuries, which eventually needed pioneering transplant surgery earlier this year.
llama3.2:1b: Richard Dunne is considering committing to Manchester City and staying at the club after turning his career around. He has improved significantly and has been linked to other clubs but wants to stay at City. The club is unlikely to bring in fresh faces in January due to lack of funds, and Keegan is set to tell this, citing Dunne's professionalism as a reason for not making any signings.
llama3.2:3b: Richard Dunne wants to commit to Manchester City and turn down interest from other clubs, saying he's improved as a player there and enjoys his time at the club. Newcastle is said to be interested in signing him, but Dunne prefers to stay with City, citing added pressure to perform due to his increased experience.

Newcastle boss Graeme Souness shows potential interest while Keegan's plans for January transfer signings are limited.  Nicky Weaver is set to return to action after injury, adding further positive development for the club.

Despite Keegan's concerns about Dunne's experience level, the 25-year-old Dubliner is still a strong contender at the top of the English football pyramid.

Newcastle manager Graeme Souness expressed interest in acquiring him in January, but Dunne underlined his desire to remain at City. Former City boss Keegan was set for another boost with goalkeeper Nicky Weaver returning from injury in an upcoming reserve game against Blackburn.

I really enjoy it at City and I want to keep that going." Keegan is expected to be told there will be no funds to bring in fresh faces in January.
smollm:1.7b: Dunne keen to commit to Manchester City for the next 5 years after turning his career around

He talks about early talks leading to interest from other clubs. Then, he responds by promising things being sorted out soon.

There are details about Keegan's controversial actions leading to Dunne's professionalism being questioned but he clarifies it.

Dunne mentions wanting to link with top clubs, enjoying the club, and emphasizing his experience and responsibility. Key points include his growing experience, playing more games than others, using that as pressure, and focusing on defense against Man City.

I also note that Keegan is set for a boost from another performer, Weaver, who has an interesting injury history but eventually got back. Dunne's performance in games at Newcastle and Middlesbrough was good defensively.

Richard Dunne is ready to commit his long-term future to Manchester City after overcoming the challenges posed by Kevin Keegan. He has shown impressive performances and is linked with potential interest from other clubs through early discussions. Graeme Souness believes Dunne's success will help him secure a bid for key striker in January's transfer window, but Dunne remains confident of staying at City due to his growth and experience as an outfield player. Keegan was questioned by Keagan about his professionalism, who clarified the situation. Dunne expresses growing experience and responsibility, emphasizing that he can use it as pressure while focusing on defending, especially against Man City.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ahead of the January transfer window, Manchester City are set to have no funds to bring in fresh faces due to fears over the future of Kevin Keegan, the club's former manager and influential figure in recruiting players at the Etihad Stadium. Despite being linked with a move for defender Richard Dunne, who has scored eight goals in 25 appearances since joining from Sunderland two years ago, the club is unlikely to make a bid for him. Former Newcastle boss Graeme Souness has been reportedly interested in signing the Irish international, but the current negotiations with City have stalled, leaving Dunne's future uncertain. Despite being linked with other clubs, Dunne insists he wants to remain at City and is ready to commit his long-term future to the Premier League champions. While Keegan has been ruled out of action for three full seasons due to knee injuries, Dunne has enjoyed a recent upturn in form, scoring eight goals in 25 appearances since joining from Sunderland in August 2017.

Keegan is expected to be told there will be no funds for the transfer window but Dunne remains determined to remain at Manchester City.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Richard Dunne, a 25-year-old Irish defender for Manchester City, is determined to extend his commitment to the club. His career was nearly derailed by former manager Kevin Keegan's criticism and threat of dismissal due to poor behavior, including arriving late and disheveled for training. However, Dunne has since transformed his performance, playing more games than any other outfield player this season, and is now highly regarded as an experienced player by Keegan.

Interest from other top clubs, like Newcastle under manager Graeme Souness, has emerged due to Dunne's resurgence. Despite these offers, Dunne remains committed to Manchester City, emphasizing his enjoyment of the team and its achievements so far. He is confident that Keegan will receive additional resources for reinforcements in the upcoming January transfer window. Additionally, goalkeeper Nicky Weaver, who has been sidelined with multiple knee injuries, is expected to return soon after a reserve game at Blackburn. This development further solidifies Dunne's desire to stay with Manchester City.
reference: "I definitely want to stay at City because I have really improved as a player here."He was once threatened with the sack by City boss Kevin Keegan but has since responded with impressive performances, prompting interest from other clubs."I really enjoy it at City and I want to keep that going."But Dunne is keen to put that period of his life behind him and said: "I've grown up a lot and the manager sees me as one of the most experienced players in the squad."I've played more games than any other outfield players this season so I can't be regarded as being a kid any more.Newcastle boss Graeme Souness is said to have been impressed enough by Dunne's turnaround in form to be ready to make a bid for the big stopper in the January transfer window.
